Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act despite absences from Canada?
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 621 days out of the required 1095; left Canada for spousal support during husband's temporary work assignment abroad; lived and worked in Canada prior to departure; paid taxes; established a home in Canada
Court_Ruling: Federal Court intervened due to errors in the Citizenship judge's assessment
Defendant_Behavior: Absence from Canada during key residency period
Grounds_for_Claim: Temporary nature of absence and maintained ties to Canada were not properly assessed
Legal_Standard: Three years of physical residence in Canada within four years preceding application, with allowance for temporary absences if ties are maintained
Assessment_Factor: Temporary nature of absence, maintenance of ties to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court - Trial Division following denial by Citizenship judge
Review_Standard: Standard of review considered due to conflicting jurisprudence
Evidence_Used: Proof of physical presence (621 days), tax records, employment history, evidence of home ownership, reason for absence (spousal support)
Application_Basis: Residency calculation and justification for absence
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of presence, purpose of travel, continuity of ties to Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of denial and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicants must accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada during the four years preceding their application; temporary absences allowed if ties to Canada are maintained
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship judge failed to adequately consider temporary nature of absence and strong ties to Canada
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision remitted for proper assessment
Harm_Assessment: Unjust denial of citizenship due to incorrect legal assessment
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged the Citizenship judge's decision denying citizenship due to insufficient residency
Evidence_Handling: Court found that relevant evidence of ties to Canada and temporary intent was not properly weighed
Evidence_Issues: Incomplete evaluation of evidence regarding temporary absence and ongoing connections to Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not met on face value (621/1095 days), but justified as temporary absence with maintained ties
Evidence_Assessment: Physical presence, intent, economic and familial ties to Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship judge erred in failing to recognize the temporary nature of the absence and the applicantâ€™s continued integration into Canadian society
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship judge (initial), Federal Court - Trial Division (appellate)
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to properly assess evidence of maintained ties and temporary intent
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied; court found decision unreasonable due to flawed analysis
